p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the fifth report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracy Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and Ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 8 February 2023.
The following 23 ministerial responses to petitions were received:

p.span: From the Minister for Social Services to a petition regarding parental leave for stay-at-home dads (EN1838)
From the Minister for the Public Service to a petition regarding age discrimination in the public service (EN2627)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding the name used for 'Persian Gulf' (EN2805)
From the Minister for Financial Services to a petition regarding early access to superannuation (EN2941)
From the Minister for Financial Services to a petition regarding increasing the superannuation concessional cap (EN2997)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding support for the people of Afghanistan (EN3164)
From the Minister for Financial Services to a petition regarding extending the temporary COVID-19 grounds for early release of superannuation (EN3190)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding assistance and logistical support to armed groups in Afghanistan (EN3199)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding humanitarian support for Tigray Ethiopia (EN3340)
From the Minister for Financial Services to a petition regarding the cost of financial advice for consumers (EN3360)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding the recognition of genocide against the Yazidi community (EN3404)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding delay on delivery of COVID-19 vaccinations to vulnerable Australians (EN3410)
From the Minster for the Public Service to a petition regarding a mandate for all public servants to be vaccinated (EN3528)
From the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister and Cabinet to a petition regarding a change in the National Anthem to Thirty Merc's "In the Summertime" (EN3689)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding joint custody arrangements in Japan (EN3897)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding the detention and release of Professor Sean Turnell in Myanmar (EN3917)
From the Minister for Defence to a petition regarding defence personnel assistance during natural disaster (EN4048)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition regarding mobile phone reception in the Lucas area (EN4060)
From the Minister for Defence to a petition regarding gender equity for frontline combat roles and conscription (EN4069)
From the Treasurer to a petition regarding a new $5 note featuring Steve Irwin (EN4471 and EN4472)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding bulk billed paediatric appointments for under 18's (EN4502)
From the Minster for Health and Aged Care to a petition regarding Nunyara Aboriginal Health Service (EN4549)
From the Minister for Social Services to a petition regarding eligibility for aged pension (EN4564)
In Report 04 presented on 6 February 2023 the incorrect petition number (EN4048) was given to a response from the Minister for Financial Services. The correct information is:
From the Minister for Financial Services to a petition regarding superannuation contributions for Members of Parliament (EN4084)
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 23 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Parental Leave
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for the email dated 19 December 2022, concerning Petition EN1838—Extending parental leave to stay at home dads.

As announced in the October 2022-23 Budget, the Albanese Government is introducing a number of changes to improve the Paid Parental Leave scheme. Under these changes, the existing two weeks of Dad and Partner Pay will be combined with the 18 weeks of Parental Leave Pay to create a single payment. This is in recognition that parenting is an equal partnership and families should be able to choose how they balance work and care arrangements.

The Paid Parental Leave scheme is intended to give working families the financial security to take time off work to care for their baby at home during the early months of their child's life. The Paid Parental Leave work test is designed to ensure the payment assists parents who have an ongoing attachment to the workforce, while providing flexibility so that working parents who are part-time, who are between jobs or who have some break between working days can still be eligible.

Subject to the passage of legislation, from 1 July 2023, the Paid Parental Leave scheme will be made more gender neutral by allowing either parent to claim Parental Leave Pay first, which will make it easier for fathers to access the payment. The changes will also allow eligible fathers and partners to access the payment irrespective of whether the birth mother meets the income test or residency requirements.

In the case that a birth mother is not eligible for Parental Leave Pay due to the work test, the non-birth parent or partner will be unable to access Parental Leave Pay. This setting supports two key objectives of the Paid Parental Leave scheme: supporting working families where both parents have a connection to the workforce, and supporting the health and wellbeing of birth mothers and children. Birth parents may still access Parental Leave Pay in the case that the non-birth parent or partner does not. While this is not entirely gender neutral, it is essential to retain this feature to support the health of birth mothers and children.

The Government will also introduce a $350,000 family income test to the scheme's eligibility criteria. Under the new arrangements, parents will satisfy the income test if they meet either the individual income test (currently $156,647) or the family income test. This will expand eligibility to the scheme, ensuring families where the birth mother is the primary income earner can access Government-funded leave, while also ensuring lower income birth mothers are not precluded from the scheme solely on the basis of their partner's income.
Thank you again for writing.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth(Petition No. EN1838)
Australian Public Service
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 22 June 2021 to the Minister for Employment, Workforce, Skills, Small and Family Business, the Hon Stuart Robert MP, regarding Petition EN2627. Your correspondence has been passed to me for response in my capacity as the Assistant Minister to the Minister for the Public Service.
The petition expresses concern regarding age diversity and discrimination within the Australian Public Service (APS) and seeks change to legislation to include reference to age discrimination.

The APS is committed to building capability through diverse workforces and inclusive workplaces. I acknowledge that it is critical to have a workforce that reflects the diversity of the Australian community.

The APS has experienced significant demographic changes over the last 40 years. In particular, the span of ages and number of generations in the APS has increased. Forty- seven per cent of the APS is now aged 45 years and older and the average retirement age has increased to 61.5 years.

The Delivering for Australians Report is part of the Government's commitment to building the capability of the APS workforce in order to better support Australians. The Report recommends strengthening the APS by recruiting, developing and promoting more people with diverse views and backgrounds. The Secretaries Board is overseeing a range of actions to increase APS diversity and inclusion. This includes doing more to retain and recruit older Australians.

Legislation currently exists to support diversity in the APS. The Public Service Act 1999, and the Australian Public Service Commissioner's Directions 2016, via the APS Employment Principles and the APS Values, recognise the need for diversity and the requirement to provide workplaces that are free from discrimination.

Additionally, the Age Discrimination Act 2004 prohibits discrimination in employment on the basis of age. It applies to young and older workers alike. This Act makes it unlawful to discriminate on the basis of age when advertising jobs; during recruitment and selection processes; when making decisions about training, transfer and promotion opportunities; and in the terms, conditions and termination of employment.
I trust this answers the petitioners' concerns about age discrimination in the APS and demonstrates our commitment to ensuring the APS is a diverse and inclusive workplace.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention. I have copied Minister Robert into this reply.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Public Service, Mr Morton(Petition No. EN2627)
Middle East
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter of 23 August 2021, regarding petition EN2805 on naming conventions for the body of water that separates Iran from the Arabian Peninsula.

International law does not regulate the nomenclature for the Gulf region and countries in the region use a variety of descriptive terms, such as 'Persian Gulf' or 'Arabian Gulf'. It has been the Australian Government's practice to use the politically neutral terms the 'Gulf' or' Gulf region'; however, the occasional use of 'Persian Gulf' in some publications reflects the cartographic history of the region.

Australia maintains friendly relations with all countries in the Gulf region. Our interests include strong trade, investment and people-to-people links, and cooperation on regional security, countering terrorism and countering violent extremism.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne(Petition No. EN2805)
COVID-19: Superannuation
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the former Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy, Senator the Hon Jane Hume, concerning Petition EN2941 on access to superannuation for people affected by COVID lockdowns. As the petition was not addressed by the previous Government, your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Superannuation receives substantial tax concessions designed to encourage people to save for their retirement in Australia. Consequently, restrictions are placed on the early withdrawal of superannuation savings to ensure they provide for genuine retirement income.

Superannuation may be accessed early on compassionate ground in limited circumstances, such as to cover expenses in respect of medical treatment, medical transport, palliative care, funerals and preventing foreclosure of a mortgage over a person's principal place of residence. Superannuation may also be released on ground of severe financial hardship if an individual has received an eligible government income support payment continuously for 26 weeks and is able to satisfy the trustee of the fund that they are unable to meet reasonable and immediate family living expenses. There are strict conditions that must be met in order to have superannuation released on any of these grounds. More information is available on the Australian Taxation Office website at: www.ato.gov.au/individuals/super/withdrawing-and-using-your-super/early-access-to-your-super/.

An important part of the Government's retirement income policy is to ensure that all members of the community have an adequate level of income in retirement and restrictions are placed on the early withdrawal of superannuation savings to ensure this.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones (Petition No. EN2941)
Superannuation
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the former Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy, Senator the Hon Jane Hume, concerning Petition EN2997 on increasing the superannuation concessional contributions cap. As the petition was not addressed by the previous Government, your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Caps on superannuation contributions are a longstanding feature of the system and reflect the fact that superannuation is intended to be used to fund retirement rather than for other purposes. Currently, individuals can make concessional (before tax) contributions to superannuation up to an annual cap of

$27,500 and non-concessional (after tax) contributions up to the annual cap of $110,000 for those with superannuation balances under $1.7 million. These caps are indexed in line with wage growth. Individuals can utilise unused portions of their concessional contributions cap under the carry-forward arrangements. This arrangement allows individuals to carry forward any unused proportion of the $27,500 concessional contributions cap for up to five years, if they have a superannuation balance of less than $500,000.

The Government considers that these arrangements strike the right balance between providing individuals with the flexibility to save for their retirement, and maintaining the fiscal sustainability and integrity of the superannuation system.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones(Petition No. EN2997)
Afghanistan
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021, regarding petition EN3164 on the situation in Afghanistan.

Australia is deeply concerned by the current situation in Afghanistan. The early days of the Taliban regime have not generated confidence. The acting Cabinet is unrepresentative, excluding women and major ethnic groups. Reports of widespread rollback of the rights of women and girls, including the reintroduction of restrictions on their access to education, services and public spaces, is disturbing.

On 24 August, I delivered Australia's national statement at the Human Rights Council's 31st Special Session on Afghanistan, expressing our grave concerns about the unfolding situation in Afghanistan—including the potential for further loss of life, suffering and human rights abuses—and the humanitarian crisis that is unfolding.

On 7 October, Australia co-sponsored a resolution in the 48th session of the Human Rights Council, establishing a mandate for a Special Rapporteur to monitor the human rights situation in Afghanistan. This role will be an important tool in ensuring accountability and transparency on human rights.

Australia will judge the Taliban regime by its actions and work with the international community to ensure they meet their obligations and commitments. It is essential that the Taliban prevents the resurgence of terrorism. I will continue to call on the Taliban regime to uphold human rights for Afghans and strongly condemn all forms of violence and discrimination, particularly against minorities, women and girls.

On 13 September, I announced Australia's commitment to contribute $100 million in humanitarian assistance for Afghanistan from 2021-24. This includes around $65 million in immediate lifesaving assistance in Afghanistan and support to the neighbouring countries hosting Afghan refugees. In addition, $35 million will be programmed to address the protracted impacts of the humanitarian crisis out to 2024. Australia will work through trusted UN humanitarian partners.
Let me assure you that Australia will continue to work with our partners to protect our shared and enduring interests on Afghanistan.
Sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne(Petition No. EN3164)
COVID-19: Income Support Payments
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the former Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy, Senator the Hon Jane Hume, concerning Petition EN3190 on extending the temporary COVID-19 grounds for the early release of superannuation. As the petition was not addressed by the previous Government, your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Superannuation receives substantial tax concessions designed to encourage people to save for their retirement in Australia. Consequently, restrictions are placed on the early withdrawal of superannuation savings to ensure they provide for genuine retirement income.

Superannuation may be accessed early on compassionate grounds in limited circumstances, such as to cover expenses in respect of medical treatment, medical transport, palliative care, funerals and preventing foreclosure of a mortgage over a person's principal place of residence. Superannuation may also be released on grounds of severe financial hardship if an individual has received an eligible government income support payment continuously for 26 weeks and is able to satisfy the trustee of the fund that they are unable to meet reasonable and immediate family living expenses. There are strict conditions that must be met in order to have superannuation released on any of these grounds. More information is available on the Australian Taxation Office website at: www.ato.gov.au/individuals/super/withdrawing-and-using-your-super/early- access-to-your-super/.

An important part of the Government's retirement income policy is to ensure that all members _of the community have an adequate level of income in retirement and restrictions are placed on the early withdrawal of superannuation savings to ensure this.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones(Petition No. EN3190)
Afghanistan
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021, regarding petition EN3199 on options for assistance and logistical support to armed groups within Afghanistan.

The Australian Government is very concerned about the situation in Afghanistan. The acting Cabinet is unrepresentative, and there are reports of a widespread rollback of the rights of women and girls. Nevertheless, supporting armed opposition groups would only fuel further violence and exacerbate the already dire humanitarian situation. Ultimately, Afghans must lead the effort to settle the form of their government.

Australia's longstanding policy is to recognise states, not governments. The Australian Government does not extend or withhold formal recognition to new governments. Australia will judge the Taliban regime by its actions and work with the international community to ensure they meet their obligations and commitments, including to prevent the resurgence of terrorism and to uphold human rights for all Afghans.

On 13 September, I announced Australia's commitment to contribute $100 million in humanitarian assistance for Afghanistan from 2021-24. This includes around $65 million in immediate lifesaving assistance in Afghanistan and support to the neighbouring countries hosting Afghan refugees. In addition, $35 million will be programmed to address the protracted impacts of the humanitarian crisis out to 2024.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne(Petition No. EN3199)
Ethiopia
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter regarding Petition Number EN3340 on Tigray, Ethiopia.

Australia is gravely concerned by the conflict in Ethiopia, and the dire humanitarian situation this has created for many Ethiopians. I have made my concerns known on many occasions and continue to call for all parties to the conflict to end hostilities and reach a negotiated solution.

The findings of the Office of the United Nations (UN) High Commissioner for Human Rights-Ethiopian Human Rights Commission joint investigation into alleged human rights abuses in Tigray are deeply concerning. All parties to the conflict are implicated, and it is essential that those responsible are held to account for their actions. Australia co-sponsored a resolution at the recent Special Session of the UN Human Rights Council on Ethiopia, establishing a committee of experts to investigate and report on human rights abuses during the conflict.

Australia is responding to the humanitarian situation in northern Ethiopia. We have provided $3 million to the World Food Programme to respond to food insecurity and $3 million to the International Committee of the Red Cross to help address the needs of the most vulnerable, including supporting survivors of sexual violence. Australia has also deployed humanitarian specialists to key UN agencies in Ethiopia to assist with the humanitarian response.
Australia continues to raise concerns regarding the conflict directly with the Ethiopian Government and at the UN Human Rights Council and the UN Security Council.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne(Petition No. EN3340)
Financial Services Industry
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the former Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy, Senator the Hon Jane Hume, concerning Petition EN3360 and the impact of recent reforms on the cost and accessibility of financial advice. As the petition was not addressed by the previous Government, your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Albanese Government is committed to ensuring Australians have access to high quality and affordable financial advice. It is for this reason that we have supported the independent review by Michelle Levy which considered how the regulatory framework could better enable the provision of high quality, accessible and affordable advice—the Quality of Advice Review. Ms Levy provided her final report to me on 16 December 2022. The Government will look to respond to the review after considering Ms Levy's recommendations.

Relevant to this petition, the Quality of Advice Review considered the fee disclosure and consent requirements, including those implemented in response to Recommendation 2.1 of the Hayne Financial Services Royal Commission. The Quality of Advice Review also had regard to the Design and Distribution Obligations as they apply to financial advisers.

Ms Levy took a thorough and considered approach to the review including holding more than 100 roundtables and stakeholder meetings and considering more than 300 written submissions. The Government looks forward to engaging further with industry as it develops and implements its response.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones(Petition No. EN3360)
Yazidi People
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 regarding the petition for the recognition of genocide against the Yazidi community (reference: EN3404).
I acknowledge the horrific experiences suffered by the Yazidi people at the hands of Da'esh, including targeted killings, kidnapping and sexual violence against women and girls.

In 2018, the Australian House of Representatives adopted a parliamentary motion condemning the atrocities perpetrated against the Yazidis by Da'esh, specifically those committed during the Sinjar massacre in August 2014, and recognising the importance of justice for Yazidi victims and survivors.

The Australian Government's position is that a determination of whether genocide has been committed is a matter for independent determination in the appropriate courts. There have been a small number of instances where Australia has labelled events as amounting to genocide following a finding by an international court or tribunal or a UN-mandated fact-finding mission.

In June 2017, Australia stated that there were reasonable grounds to believe ISIL may have committed genocide against Yazidis in Northern Iraq. This statement followed conclusions in the 2016 report of the Independent International Commission of Inquiry on the Syrian Arab Republic that actions by ISIL against the Yazidis of Sinjar amounted to genocide.

I wish to take this opportunity to reiterate Australia's strong support for the Yazidi community. Since 2015, Australia has resettled over 5,500 Yazidi refugees through our Offshore Humanitarian Program. The target of the resettlement program has been female survivors of Da'esh captivity, and their immediate families.

Australia also continues to raise our concerns for the suffering of the Yazidi community in various international fora, including most recently on 7 July 2021, in a national statement at the Interactive Dialogue on the Syrian Commission of Inquiry at the UN Human Rights Council.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne(Petition No. EN3404)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

1 refer to correspondence of 22 November 2021 from the Standing Committee on Petitions regarding petition number EN3410. While this petition was directed to the previous government, I have provided this response on advice from the Department of Health and Aged Care.

Petition EN3410 concerned a request to the Australian Government to respond to delays in the delivery of COVID-19 vaccinations to people with disability and vulnerable cohorts in Residential Disability Accommodation and Aged Care Settings.

From the start of the vaccine rollout program, high-risk groups—including people with disability in residential settings and their workers—have had priority access to COVID-19 vaccines relative to the general population. Five vaccination channels were made available for residents and workers of eligible disability residential accommodation settings since Phase la of the COVID-19 pandemic, including through:
Commonwealth in-reach (which included offering day clinics, mini-hubs, or direct in-reach activity)
community-based vaccination hubs specific to disability (with vaccination services delivered by commercial vaccination providers)
state and territory vaccination clinics
primary care settings (including general practice, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Community Controlled Health Services, Commonwealth Vaccination Clinics, and pharmacies)
GP in-reach (for sites where there is interest from both GPs and disability providers).

The Commonwealth's Vaccination Administration Provider Program (VAPP) has provided in-reach support for residential disability settings. Through VAPP, the Commonwealth has completed the primary course and booster dose rollouts and is at 99.82% completion for the fourth dose in-reach rollout.
The Commonwealth in-reach Disability Vaccine Primary Course Rollout commenced on 24 February 2021 in line with Phase 1A of the rollout and finalised on 13 May 2022.

The primary course rollout reported 8,608 shared disability residential accommodation settings as having completed all eligible vaccinations at the site, with 5,485 of those receiving primary course vaccinations through in-reach services and 2,868 receiving vaccinations through alternative channels.
The Commonwealth in-reach Disability Booster Dose Rollout commenced on

8 November 2021 and finalised on 2 June 2022. The booster dose rollout reported 5,390 sites completed, with 2,813 sites receiving a booster dose through in-reach clinics and 2,519 sites reported as accessing booster dose vaccination through other channels.

As at 12 January 2023, the Commonwealth in-reach Disability Vaccine Fourth Dose Rollout has reported 3,284 (99.82%} sites completed. Many of these sites were identified as eligible for fourth dose support during the pre-allocation process based on having received VAPP In-reach support in the booster dose rollout. However, this did not restrict other sites from obtaining assistance. Complete sites include 1,419 (49.0%} sites that have received or are yet to receive VAPP In-reach, 1,168 (35.5%} sites reported as accessing vaccinations through alternative channels, 514 (15.6%} sites that were offered but declined in-reach and 173 (5.3%} sites unavailable for an in-reach visit.

Occasionally there were long lead times from the point of initial allocation of a site to a vaccine provider, to when the site received in-reach vaccination. The delays and long lead times, whilst disappointing, were to be expected in cases where:
consent to receive vaccination was not received
participants at a site were not yet eligible to receive vaccinations
there was an outbreak at the site, meaning residents were not immediately eligible to receive vaccination
the Disability Service Provider (DSP) was unresponsive
the request for vaccination was complex.

In managing the allocation of vaccine providers to disability residential sites, the department employed the following strategies to ensure that vaccines were administered in a timely and equitable manner.

Once an expression of interest or request for vaccination was received, the department committed to allocating that site to a vaccine provider within 48 hours, subject to the complexity of the request.
Once a site was allocated, the department would set hard deadlines on vaccine providers to contact the DSP from the point of allocation, to ensure no unnecessary delays.

The department received weekly End-of-Day and scheduling reports to monitor the scheduling and completion of clinics for allocated sites. Where an allocated site did not have a scheduled clinic date, the department would actively engage with the allocated vaccine provider and the DSP to ensure there were minimal delays in delivery of vaccinations to sites.
The department would engage and meet with vaccine providers weekly to identify any obstacles to delivery.

The department would allocate sites to vaccine providers based on the vaccine providers responsiveness and ability to provide outcomes in a timely manner. Vaccine providers that did not meet their obligations were not given allocations, or had sites re-allocated from them to another provider.

At various stages of the rollouts, stakeholders such as the National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA), the National Disability Insurance Scheme Commission and the Department of Social Services assisted with the rollout and helped to engage DSPs that were identified as having a large number of outstanding sites requiring vaccinations. This included referral of unresponsive DSPs to the NDIA for investigation where they were not meeting their duty to engage with the department.
I trust this provides a response to Petition EN3410.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler(Petition No. EN3410)
Vaccination
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 14 February 2022 regarding 'Petition EN3548' (the Petition), as received by the Standing Committee on Petitions of the House of Representatives. The Petition requests that the House of Representatives mandate COVID-19 vaccinations for all public servants including the staff of members of Parliament.

You have referred the Petition to me as the Minister for the Public Service, being the responsible Minister for the administration of the matter raised in the Petition. The referral to me has been made pursuant to Standing Order 209(a) and (b). I respond to the request in the Petition on behalf of the Government and have provided some advice below concerning the steps taken to ensure the health and safety of Government employees and their clients, in response to COVID-19.

The Government has consistently supported and strongly encouraged all Australian Government employees, including staff of members of Parliament, to get vaccinated against COVID-19. This is reflected in the Australian Public Service Commission's (APSC) Circular 2021/01: COVID-19 vaccinations published on 8 February 2021. This Circular requires agencies to provide maximum support to enable employees to get vaccinated, including paid time off and covering reasonable travel expenses. Additionally, as the Circular notes, Australian Government employees are expected to comply with the terms of relevant state and territory government COVID-19 related public health orders. This includes any applicable orders mandating vaccination as a prerequisite for attending and performing work.

The APSC on 6 October 2022 also published Circular 2021/09: COVID-19 vaccination policies in Australian Government workplaces, which states that it is the responsibility of individual Agency Heads to consider the extent that lawful and reasonable directions are necessary to require their employees, or a subset, to get vaccinated in the absence of an applicable public health order.

This Circular also notes that any decision by an agency head to issue a direction to their employees to get vaccinated should be supported by a comprehensive risk assessment and be tailored to each agency's specific circumstances. This includes consideration of work settings, work health and safety obligations, transmission risks and other relevant factors. In this respect, Government employees are subject to the same work, health and safety requirements as employers in other sectors and must ensure a vaccination mandate imposed on employees is lawful and reasonable.

Australian Government employers have also been incorporating a variety of measures to ensure the health and safety of their employees and others in the workplace such as clients. These efforts go beyond encouraging vaccinations and mandating vaccinations in limited circumstances, and include remote working, social distancing, occupancy limits, office cleanliness guidelines, requirements around the wearing of masks and the use of physical barriers in customer-facing work. For example, in January and February 2022, agencies have largely returned to working from home arrangements in response to the evolving Omicron variant, where operational requirements allow.

I am confident these measures and efforts, coupled with the Government's strong encouragement to get vaccinated, will limit the potential for community transmission of COVID-19 in Australian Government workplaces, particularly those that are public facing. In fact, I am very pleased to note that there are already high rates of vaccinations (two Therapeutic Goods Administration approved doses) against COVID-19 (for persons aged 16 and over) across Australia (94.01%) and, in particular, the Australian Capital Territory (greater than 99%), where a large numbers of Australian Government employees work.

I want to thank the members of the public who wrote to the Committee to raise the Petition and their genuine interest in ensuring Australian Government employees and the community they serve are protected against COVID-19. The Government and its employers remain highly engaged in our ongoing efforts to limit the risk of transmission in Commonwealth workplaces.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Public Service, Mr Morton(Petition No. EN3548)
Australian National Anthem
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter dated 14 February 2022, regarding a petition presented to the House of Representatives on 14 February 2022 EN3689. I sincerely apologise for the delay in responding to you.

The words and tune of the Australian National Anthem were proclaimed by the Governor-General of Australia on 19 April 1984, after extensive surveys of national opinion, starting in the 1970s. The Australian National Anthem remains widely accepted by Australians.

You may be aware that on 1 January 2021, the second line of the Australian National Anthem changed from 'For we are young andfree' to 'For we are one andfree'. The change was made for all Australians.
The Government has no further plans to change this important national symbol.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton(Petition No. EN3689)
Japan
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email regarding petition EN3897 and joint custody arrangements in Japan.

The Australian Government is concerned about the number of Australian-Japanese children subject to custody disputes and parental abduction in Japan. We are aware of disputes where non-custodial parents in Japan have been unable to exercise their parental rights. These are matters for the Japanese courts. However, we consider it important that children at the centre of parental conflict are able to maintain links with both parents, and extended family.

The Australian Government continues to make representations to Japanese authorities to encourage Japan to find a solution acceptable to all and respectful of the best interests of the children. I have raised our concerns on this issue directly with my counterpart.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) is actively engaged on these issues working to improve access for Australian parents, making representations directly to the Japanese Government, and engaging with our likeminded partners on approaches. Our embassy in Tokyo continues to provide consular support to affected parents in accordance with the Consular Services Charter.
DFAT officials will continue to engage Australian parents on these issues, and our advocacy, to ensure affected Australians are kept appraised of our progress.

Parents of Australian children can seek consular assistance regarding child custody issues from the department's Consular and Crisis Management Division by email: centre.conops@dfat.gov.au or by telephone: 1300 555 135.

Parents whose children have been wrongfully removed from Australia, or wrongfully retained in Japan, along with parents in Australia who wish to enforce their rights of access to their children in Japan may be eligible to make an application under the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction {Hague Convention).

Information about the Hague Convention can be found at: https://www.ag.gov.au/families-and-marriage/families/international-family-law-and-children. The Australian Central Authority in the Attorney-General's Department can be contacted at: australiancentralauthority@ag.gov.au
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne(Petition No. EN3897)
Myanmar
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter regarding petition EN3917 concerning Professor Sean Turnell. As with the many expressions of support for Professor Turnell since his detention, this petition confirms the depth of community backing for him.
The Australian Government recognises the concerns for Professor Turnell's welfare during his detention in Myanmar: concerns we share absolutely.
As you know from my statement of 6 February 2022, the Australian Government considers Professor Turnell's detention to be unjust. We reject the allegations against him.

I assure you that our advocacy for Professor Turnell's release continues without pause. As I do personally when I speak to my counterparts in the region and more widely, Australian officials throughout our diplomatic network take every opportunity to press Professor Turnell's case.
This means the regime in Myanmar can be in no doubt about the importance and urgency with which Australia and the international community view Professor Turnell's release.
We are using diplomatic and defence channels to ensure our messages are heard by the regime in Myanmar. It can be in no doubt about Australia's views.
Our calls for Professor Turnell's release are also backed by Australia's international partners, many of whom know Professor Turnell through their own support for Myanmar's development.
At the same time, our Embassy is providing Professor Turnell with all possible consular support.
While my privacy obligations prevent me from sharing further details, I can assure you that the Australian Government stands by Professor Turnell and his family.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne(Petition No. EN3917)
Natural Disasters
Dear Chair,
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 on behalf of the Petitions Committee, reference number EN4048, regarding Australian Defence Force (ADF) assistance during natural disasters.

The prime role of the ADF is the defence of the nation. The ADF has however been actively involved in supporting the communities affected by natural disasters continuously since late 2019. It does so as part of the Commonwealth Government's support to state and territory governments, who have primary responsibility for responding to natural disasters. You would be aware the ADF has effected this type of support from time to time for disasters.

Recently, the ADF established Operation FLOOD ASSIST 22-2 as part of the whole of Commonwealth Government response to flooding in Victoria and New South Wales. The support provided by the ADF included flood preparations, sand bagging, welfare checks, evacuation support, logistics and road clearance, as well as early recovery support. Rotary wing aerial support included rescue support, damage assessments and logistics support to isolated communities.
It is worth noting that the Report of the Royal Commission into National Natural Disasters of 20201dentlfied that-
"7. 7 Generally, the public perception was that the ADF could assist in every aspect and was always readily available.

span.span: 7.8 This is not, in fact, the case. Nor is it a reasonable expectation of the ADF. "

p.span: While the ADF is postured to support the response to emergent domestic crises, the provision of prolonged support—particularly in non-core roles—is adversely impacting on preparedness, operations, regional engagement, retention and modernisation. This coincides with a period of strategic uncertainty and increasing security-specific demands on the ADF, particularly in the India-Pacific. As the Royal Commission noted in its Report-

span.span: "7.16 The ADF has finite capacity and capability. The capacity and capability of the ADF to respond to natural disasters can be affected by its commitment to its priorities, both domestic and international. The ADF should not be seen as a first responder for natural disasters, nor relied on as such.

p.span: This accords with the Government's view that the ADF needs to be the responder of last resort, not first resort.
The Commonwealth Government works closely with the states and territories affected to understand the nature and extent of the impact, and to respond accordingly.

In accordance with the Australian Government Crisis Management Framework (AGCMF), National Emergency Management Australia (NEMA} coordinates the Commonwealth approach to preparing for, responding to, and recovering from crises. During a natural disaster, state or territories request Commonwealth assistance, including ADF assistance, through NEMA. These requests are made when the emergency response authority has exhausted their capacity to respond, or cannot respond in sufficient time, or they require a specialist response that only the ADF can provide. Defence maintains short notice, specialist capabilities that may, under Commonwealth direction, assist civilian communities and civilian authorities.
Defence remains postured to provide additional support to Emergency Services upon request through the National Emergency Management Agency
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles(Petition No. EN4048)
Telecommunications
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 20 September 2022 to the Hon Kristy McBain MP, Minister for Regional Development, Local Government and Territories, regarding Petition EN4060, requesting telecommunications companies fix poor mobile reception in Lucas, Victoria. Minister McBain has referred your letter to me for response, as the issue raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

I acknowledge the concerns expressed by residents in Lucas about poor mobile coverage in the area. Following your correspondence, the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts contacted Optus and Telstra regarding the level of mobile coverage in the Lucas area.

Optus acknowledges that the Lucas area experiences mobile coverage and capacity issues. This is exacerbated by the amount of growth and development in the area. However, Optus has three new mobile base stations proposed for the area which it expects will provide new coverage and reduce mobile traffic at existing sites, assisting with coverage and capacity limitations currently being experienced. The three proposed base stations are Lucas—proposed completion date quarter one of 2023; Alfredton South—proposed completion date quarter three of 2023; and Alfredton Reserve—proposed completion date quarter two of 2024.

Telstra also acknowledges that growth in the Lucas area has been significant and it has been working for some time to find accessible land to build new mobile infrastructure to improve services to the area. However, finding accessible land that will provide the desired service outcome for residents of the area has been and continues to be a challenge for Telstra.

Telstra understands the need for infrastructure to provide improved mobile service in the Lucas area, and has been working closely with the local council and community representatives to deliver a viable solution at a suitable site. Through this process, Telstra has now identified a potential site candidate for a new base station, and submitted a Development Application (DA) to council on 13 October 2022.

At this time, Telstra is unable to provide a clear timeframe on completion of a new base station subject to obtaining the required DA approvals, as well as the scale and complexity of undertaking associated work such as site access, and connection of power and backhaul.

Regarding existing coverage in Lucas, there are a number of factors that can influence mobile coverage. These include capacity issues as previously identified, local terrain and other physical obstacles such as trees and buildings (including their internal structure) that may interrupt the signal received from the nearest mobile base station.
The mobile network operators (Optus, Telstra and TPG Telecom) have products available to improve mobile reception, including the use of an external antenna or authorised repeater.

Wi-Fi calling is another option available on the mobile carrier's networks for use with a compatible device allowing some customers with a broadband connection to call and text over a Wi-Fi connection. This can be particularly helpful for people experiencing poor or no mobile coverage inside their home, by providing an alternative form of com1ectivity. People can obtain accessories and advice on the best solution by contacting their service provider.

The NBN Co Limited website indicates that the National Broadband Network (NBN) is now available in Lucas, with construction unde1way in the newer areas. If Lucas residents have not done so already, they may wish to contact their preferred retail service provider regarding broadband connectivity. More information can be found on NBN Co's check your address webpage at www.nbnco.com.au/connect-home-or-business/check-your-address.
The Australian Government is committed to increasing connectivity, bridging the digital divide, improving mobile coverage and protecting communities against natural disaster.

The Government is investing over $2.2 billion into regional telecommunications over the next five years. This includes $656 million under the Better Connectivity Plan for Regional and Rural Australia (the Plan) and more than $1.6 billion to improve NBN services across regional and remote Australia. This represents a major increase in regional communications funding and one of the most significant commitments to regional communications since the establishment of the NBN.

As part of the Plan, the Government has committed $400 million to improve mobile coverage along major regional roads, in under-served regional communities, and to improve mobile network resilience. A further $200 million will be available for place-based regional connectivity projects, $30 million to improve on-fa1m connectivity and $20 million for an independent audit of mobile coverage to establish an evidence baseline to guide and better target future priorities. These programs are under development and will provide opportunities for further digital projects to be undertaken in regional Victoria to improve connectivity.

The Government is also providing $6 million to further support regional, rural and remote Australians by extending the Regional Tech Hub (the Hub), a platform serving as a trusted source of free and independent advice on telecommunications services. The Hub can assist Lucas residents troubleshoot and identify solutions to existing connectivity issues. This funding extension will continue to provide better consumer awareness and improve their connectivity literacy, to ensure rural and regional communities can get connected sooner.

The Hub is managed and operated by the National Farmers Federation, in partnership with the Australian Communications Consumer Action Network, and includes a website, online helpdesk, phone support line and social media access through Facebook and Twitter. Information on the Hub can be found on its website at www.regionaltechhub.org.au or people can contact the hotline for assistance on 1300 081 029.
Further details on the Government's commitments under the Better Connectivity Plan for Regional and Rural Australia are available at www.infrastrncture.gov.au/bcp.

My department also maintains a central register of locations which have been the subject of a complaint concerning poor or non-existent mobile coverage. I can confirm that Lucas has been added to the register. This register is used by the Government to inform future policy decisions and is also made available to all bidders for their consideration when applying for funding under future Government programs.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland(Petition No. EN4060)
Defence
Dear Chair,
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 on behalf of the Petitions Committee reference number EN4069, regarding military conscription and gender parity.

I wish to clarify that this response relates to the broader underlying issues touched on by the petition and should not be seen in any way as an endorsement or approval of the language of the petition, which many Australians could view as offensive or hurtful.

The Australian Government believes that maintaining a well-trained and highly professional Australian Defence Force (ADF) is the most effective way of delivering on Australia's Defence requirements. The nature of military service in the current environment is such that our service personnel require substantial training to enable them to operate in complex and

varied situations. To train civilians or even a conscript force to a competent and safe level would require significant resources and take those highly trained and experienced personnel away from their primary role of delivering Defence capability to the nation.
The Government does not plan to introduce military conscription.

Defence continues to make substantial progress in addressing a range of issues relevant to people who are currently under-represented in Defence, including women, Indigenous Australians, people with disability and people from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds.

Lead the Way: Defence Transformation Strategy recognises that Defence's ability to successfully deliver on the Government's strategic objectives hinges on our people, and that continuous improvement efforts are supported by a workforce that reflects, and draws from, the Australian community which Defence serves.

All Australians can pursue a career in the ADF based solely on considerations of eligibility and suitability—including aptitude, physical capacity and potential. All ADF employment categories are open to women, including combat roles. Defence does not discriminate on the basis of gender for any role in Defence and increasing female representation within the ADF continues to be a priority.

The Australian Government agreed to the removal of gender restrictions from ADF combat roles in September 2012. On 1 January 2016, Defence began direct recruitment into all combat role employment categories. Defence exemptions under the Sex Discrimination Act were withdrawn in 2018.

In 1992, the ban on same-sex attracted men and women serving in the Australian Defence Force {ADF) was lifted, and in 2010 the ban on transgender individuals serving was also lifted. The removal of policies previously banning these individuals allows LGBTI ADF members to serve openly, without fear of losing their career and marked the beginning of a journey, reflecting Defence's commitment to a fair, inclusive and equitable workplace.
As one of Australia's largest employers, Defence is committed to increasing women's representation within its ADF workforce by adopting targets across the Tri-Services:

Navy is committed to increasing women's representation to 25 per cent by 2025, with an internal stretch goal of 35 per cent by 2035. Army achieved the 15 per cent target of women's representation in February 2021 and has set revised targets of 18 per cent by 2025 and 20 per cent by 2035. Air Force achieved the 25 per cent target of women's representation in February 2021 and has set a revised target of 35 per cent by 2030.

A diverse workforce with an inclusive culture enhances Defence's capability and effectiveness and is a key priority in Pathway to Change: Evolving Defence Culture 2017-2022. Defence capability is reliant on the ability to attract and retain the best possible talent regardless of background, gender, age, culture, religion, ability or sexual orientation.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles(Petition No. EN4069)
Australian Currency
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4471 and EN4472 on introducing a new $5 banknote featuring Steve Irwin. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Reserve Bank has decided to update the $5 banknote to feature a new design that honours the culture and history of the First Australians. This new design will replace the portrait of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II. The other side of the $5 banknote will continue to feature the Australian Parliament.
This decision by the Reserve Bank Board follows consultation with the Australian Government, which supports this change.

The Bank will consult with First Australians in designing the $5 banknote. The new banknote will take a number of years to be designed and printed. In the meantime, the current $5 banknote will continue to be issued. It will be able to be used even after the new banknote is issued.
Thank you again for your letter.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers(Petitions Nos EN4471 and EN4472)
Medicare
Dear Chair,

Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN4502 requesting that all minors (that is children under 18 years of age) in Australia receive bulk-billed treatment from specialist paediatrician consultations.
Medicare is the Australian Government-funded universal health insurance scheme. It was introduced in 1984 to provide Australians with high-quality and accessible health care.
The Medicare program includes free treatment as a public hospital patient and subsidised medical services through the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS).

The MBS bulk billing arrangements are set out in section 20A of the Health Insurance Act 1973 (Act) which serves a long-standing policy objective of limiting patient expenditure on medical services by ensuring that medical practitioners receive the certainty of payment in exchange for restraint on the fees they charge.

While the Government sets the Medicare benefit for each service, health practitioners are free to set their own fees for the services they provide. This includes bulk billing the patient at no cost, or charging the patient an out-of-pocket amount.

In considering whether to charge a payment to an individual patient, and the level of any fees above the Medicare benefit, the Government encourages providers to consider a patient's personal circumstances when making decisions about the fees they charge.

The Government also assists patients with their out-of-pocket costs through a number of Medicare safety nets, including the Extended Medicare Safety Net (EMSN). The EMSN provides an increase in benefits of up to 80% of the out-of-pocket costs for a patient once the threshold has been reached, including a lower threshold for concessional patients. All out-of-pocket hospital costs (the difference between the Medicare rebate and the amount a doctor charges the patient) counts towards the EMSN.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler(Petition No. EN4502)
First Nations Australians: Health Care
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 regarding petition EN4549 regarding Nunyara Aboriginal Health Service (Nunyara). I apologise for the delay in responding.

As Minister for Health and Aged Care I am committed to ensuring that organisations funded under the Indigenous Australians' Health Programme deliver high quality, culturally appropriate primary health care to the local Aboriginal community.

Nunyara is an independent community-controlled organisation incorporated under the Associations Incorporation Act 1985 (SA), with a Board and senior management responsible for the governance and management of the organisation. As such, the petitioners may wish to raise their concerns with Nunyara directly if they not yet. Nunyara's complaint handling process is outlined at www.nunyara.org.au/complaints. If the petitioners are dissatisfied with Nunyara's initial response, they may also raise their concerns directly with the Board.
If the Board does not adequately address the concerns raised, the petitioners may choose to raise the issues with:

the Aboriginal Health Council of South Australia (AHCSA), of which Nunyara is a member, at www.ahcsa.org.au. AHCSA is the peak body representing Aboriginal community-controlled health services in South Australia.
the South Australian Health and Community Services Complaints Commissioner at www.hcscc.sa.gov.au.
Nunyara's regulating body, Consumer and Business Affairs, South Australia at associations@sa.gov.au or on 131 882.
Given the nature of the issues raised in the petition, I have also asked relevant departmental staff to review and follow up with the Nunyara Board, as appropriate.
Thank you for bringing this issue to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler(Petition No. EN4549)
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence dated 28 November 2022, concerning Petition EN4564 (the petition) on changing the eligibility for the Age Pension.
The Australian Government is committed to a welfare system that supports the most vulnerable, encourages those who are able to work or study, and is sustainable for future generations.

The Age Pension is a targeted payment to support a basic, acceptable standard of living for seniors who are no longer expected to work to due to their age, and who are unable to fully support themselves due to their limited income and assets.
As a non-contributory social security payment, the Age Pension is not based on past income or contributions, or taxes paid during a person's working life.
To claim and be granted the Age Pension, a person must:
generally be an Australian resident and in Australia at the time of their claim;
have resided in Australia for at least 10 years; and
be of Age Pension age.

Payment is also subject to having income and assets below certain limits. Providing targeted assistance is consistent with the basic principle that individuals should be required to draw on their own resources before calling upon the Government. This also ensures that the Government is able to meet important budgetary objectives, such as spending on health and education, while keeping taxes low.
The petition suggests changing the eligibility criteria for the Age Pension to limit it to those who have worked for over 20 years.

Providing an Age Pension to people purely on the basis of their employment history is inconsistent with the principles of social security in Australia. The Age Pension provides targeted support to senior Australians with limited means.

The Age Pension is part of the broader retirement income system, which is funded through a mix of consolidated revenue, employer contributions and employee contributions. The system is based on 3 parts, or pillars:
compulsory employer superannuation contributions through the Superannuation Guarantee, supported by taxation concessions;
voluntary private savings, including personal superannuation contributions which are supported by taxation concessions; and

the taxpayer-funded means-tested Age Pension, which provides a safety net for people who are unable to support themselves fully in retirement and supplements the retirement incomes of those with lower levels of private savings.
People who have a lengthy employment history may benefit from the first 2 pillars (Superannuation Guarantee and voluntary savings), which provide a comprehensive framework for retirement savings.

In most cases, retirement incomes of senior Australians are a combination of the above components, with the Age Pension as the key component for those who have not been able to accumulate sufficient superannuation and other savings, due to unemployment, disability or caring responsibilities.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth(Petition No. EN4564)
PETITIONS
Statements

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): Today I am only tabling ministerial responses. Because of the timing of committee meetings over December and January, there are no petitions ready to present. However, the holiday period did not show any reduction in the number of petitions and requests. There are currently 75 petitions on the website open for signatures that will be presented in future sitting weeks.

In September 2022 there were 171 outstanding ministerial responses to petitions that had been presented in the previous parliament. Late last year, the committee conducted a review of responses that had not yet been received and sent out reminders to ministers of their obligation to respond to petitions. This obligation comes from the House and includes petitions that were referred to a former minister or former government.

The reminders led to an increase of responses to older petitions from current ministers. The review has also resulted in a few responses from previous ministers coming to light that had not yet been presented. These responses are being presented today. The committee is checking its processes to ensure all responses are presented in a timely way in the future.
I look forward to updating the House further on the work of the Petitions Committee.
BILLS
Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill 2022
Report from Committee

Ms THWAITES (Jagajaga) (10:03): On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I present the committee's advisory report, incorporating dissenting reports, on the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill 2022.

This was an important inquiry, and I thank all who participated and the committee members. This will be the first time in 24 years that Australia will have a referendum. A lot has changed in 24 years, including how our elections are run and how voters engage in elections. It is important that Australians continue to have an electoral system that is modern and that meets our current-day needs. The bill referred to our committee for consideration does this work. It modernises the way referendums are run so that this year, when Australians go to vote, they'll have a voting experience very similar to last year's federal election, including early voting centres and postal voting, a timely count of ballots, and transparency when it comes to authorisation of campaign materials, the financial disclosure and foreign donations framework and matching measures in the Electoral Act.

In conducting its work, the committee received submissions from members of the public, constitutional and legal experts, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander representative groups and others. I thank them all. The committee heard there was important ability in holding this referendum for us to update the experience of voters and bring it into line with their experience of voting in a federal election. The AEC told us that, essentially, this means that when people go to vote their experience will be very similar to what it was on election day.

The committee heard there are further opportunities that should be considered as part of the referendum experience to build on our modern electoral system, to allow especially for improved enfranchisement and participation particularly amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The current rate of enrolment amongst Indigenous Australians is around 82 per cent nationally. That is not good enough. The AEC is confident that trials of new measures will further boost enrolment in coming months. The AEC told the committee it saw opportunities in this referendum to improve this participation. That includes conducting remote area mobile polling for up to 19 days ahead of the referendum date; trialling the provision of secure telephone voting in certain circumstances; and providing for secure on-the-day enrolment, enabling a potential new voter to cast a declaration vote that is admitted to the count once their enrolment is approved and processed. The committee urges the government to give serious consideration to supporting these measures that improve participation and enrolment. It is critically important that we allow all Australians to have their say as part of this referendum.

The committee also considered how information has been and should be provided during a referendum. There were a wide range of views the committee heard on this, including both for and against the use of the traditional yes/no pamphlet. Some legal and constitutional experts told the inquiry that, in the past, the pamphlet has not worked as intended to. Professor George Williams noted:
The pamphlets are often full of not only misleading statements but sometimes lies that we know to be false.
He added that he supported the removal of the pamphlet but was troubled that merely removing it was not enough, and that we should look at what we replace the pamphlet with.

Professor Anne Twomey said that such pamphlets have previously been used to provide the community with emotive, misleading and inaccurate statements. She said she wouldn't mourn the loss of the 'yes' or 'no' case but stressed there was a need for something substantial to replace it. Others stated that the pamphlet remains a valuable document for voters, providing them with the views of their elected representatives. The Australian Human Rights Commission said the pamphlet was an official source of information that summarises the key arguments for and against. The Central Land Council expressed concern that, without a physical pamphlet, older people and those in remote communities might feel they didn't have reliable access to information.

While views on the pamphlet varied, there was widespread agreement about the need for information to educate and inform voters about the referendum and help them make up their minds. That's why the committee recommends the government considers how best it can ensure all Australians are provided with clear, factual and impartial information as part of the referendum. This includes, and the government has announced that part of providing this information will be, a yes/no pamphlet. This will be coupled with broader efforts in providing the information Australians will need to feel assured they have been informed before they go to the polls.
With these considerations and recommendations in mind, the committee supports the passage of the bill.
Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Mr STEVENS (Sturt) (10:08): On behalf of opposition members of the committee I make a few comments on the tabling of the report. There is a dissenting report. The previous speaker has just foreshadowed the government's position regarding the formal pamphlet. There was a lot of hot debate and a proposition of potentially removing that tradition. It seems the government's position has changed on that, which we welcome.

This was an inquiry into the machinery of referenda perpetually into the future; this could be a statute that applies to many referenda into the future, and it shouldn't be narrowly viewed specifically towards an imminent referendum related to the constitutional amendment for the Voice to Parliament. Regardless I don't think the fundamental principles of how we conduct referenda in this country should differ, no matter what the question is. It's highly concerning to those of us in the opposition to see propositions—and we, in our dissenting report, indicate we don't support the proposition—of not having a proper, formal case protected through legislation for each side of the proposition to change the Constitution in any case in which we are looking to change the Constitution. That is proposed in this legislation, and we are very much opposed both to not having a formal 'yes' and 'no' case and to not properly financially resourcing each of those cases. Obviously that principle must include equal financial resourcing to each case. Of course, the particular legislative instrument to hold any particular referendum tends to encapsulate how the government intends to resource those cases, but we believe that should always involve equal funding.

I am really concerned, frankly—we all have political experience in this chamber—that any attempt to rig the system and to suggest or make changes that some people might believe are designed to facilitate a certain outcome is actually going to achieve the complete opposite political objective. We understand that the public funding of 'yes' and 'no' cases is always going to be a small proportion of the total amount of resources deployed into a campaign. That's the case in our actual elections, as we know. So there is going to be a 'yes' campaign and a 'no' campaign in any referendum, including for the Voice to Parliament. If it becomes the position of the parliament to change the law to remove the tradition of providing taxpayer resources equally to each of the cases, I think the damage to any effort to change the Constitution will far outweigh whatever resourcing an argument against changing the Constitution would have provided in the court of public opinion through the expenditure of those funds.

So we are opposed to the principle but also quite surprised that there is anyone who thinks they are helping an outcome to be achieved by starving it of taxpayer resources. It's going to achieve the opposite result. It is very difficult to change the Constitution. We know that. We've got a lot of evidence. We try, but it rarely occurs. At the most recent time, the republic referendum in 1999, we had formal, official 'yes' and 'no' cases, and appropriate financing was provided towards that. I think that any kind of trickery or rigging of in the system and effectively trying to advantage one side of a debate over the other will only increase scepticism amongst the people of the country and will only contribute to the defeat of whatever proposition is put to them.

It will be difficult to change the Constitution any time we try, no matter what the proposition is. Why you would want to add and be saddled with the additional challenge of having made a legislative change that unwinds the precedent of supporting proper debate on changing our Constitution in this nation is absolutely mystifying to those of us in the coalition. We urge the government to dramatically reconsider the message it will send and the damage it would inflict on attempts to change the Constitution by saying we don't want to have properly resourced arguments for and against that change. I think the people will react quite strongly against that change, and it will dramatically doom future attempts to change the Constitution that may or may not have credibility, because the politicians have rigged the system against it. (Time expired)

Ms CHANEY (Curtin) (10:13): I'm broadly supportive of the government's recommendations in the advisory report on the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill 2022. In particular, I am glad to see a recommendation to support increased enrolment and participation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in remote communities and the uncontroversial updating of the mechanics of how we run referenda. On a broader note, after this referendum we should do a compressive review of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act to reflect the developments of the last century so that last-minute changes don't need to be made through new legislation relating to each referendum.

I'm supportive of the somewhat vague recommendation that the Australian government ensure appropriate structures and mechanisms are put in place to ensure impartial information is made available. While I have some concerns about the veracity of the information to be included in an official yes/no pamphlet, I am not against the opposition's suggestion that having an official yes/no pamphlet may be useful for the diminishing part of our community that does not get its information from the internet. I support this change.

I would like to speak briefly to the three additional comments I make in the report. It's essential that we do a better job of ensuring truth in political advertising. This is broader than the proposed Voice referendum, but concerns about racist misinformation in this context are real and sharpen the focus on truth in advertising because of the potential damage that could be done. I accept that it will be difficult to establish a robust truth-in-political-advertising regime in time for the referendum. In the short term, and so as not to interfere with the timing of the referendum, a compromise position could be to establish an independent panel to fact-check information disseminated in the referendum campaign. This panel is consistent with the government's second recommendation, to establish structures and mechanisms to ensure impartial information, and could play a role in that function as well. The panel could also play a role in determining the wording of the question, and many expert witnesses backed this idea.

Another broad area of reform that will surface in relation to the referendum is financial disclosures. The bill recommends the same excessively high threshold of $14,500 and late timing for disclosure of who's supporting the 'yes' and 'no' campaigns. I recognise that this would create a reporting burden, but there is overwhelming community support to improve the transparency of who is funding political campaigns before we vote, and I think it would be a good idea for any organisation campaigning on the Voice, either way, to think about the fact that their support will be made public. In relation to financial disclosures, I would support a recommendation for greater transparency, in line with most states, with more immediate disclosure of all donations above $1,000.

For such an important referendum for the future of the country, truth and transparency are vital, and I urge the government to consider improvements to this end in the implementation of the legislation.
The SPEAKER: The time allocated for statements on this report has concluded.
Ms THWAITES (Jagajaga) (10:16): I move:
That the House take note of the report.
Debate adjourned.
Reference to Federation Chamber
Ms THWAITES (Jagajaga) (10:16): by leave—I move:
That the order of the day be referred to the Federation Chamber for debate.
Question agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Electoral Amendment (Cleaning up Political Donations) Bill 2023

p.span: Commonwealth Electoral Amendment (Cleaning up Political Donations) Bill 2023
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Wilkie.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr WILKIE (Clark) (10:17): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Late last year, with the passage of the National Anti-Corruption Commission Bill, Australians saw a glimmer of hope that this place was ready to take integrity seriously. It was a genuinely significant occasion, and, despite the flaws in the commission, the government should be commended for following through with its election commitment of legislating a strong, independent national integrity agency.

But our work is obviously far from done because, to restore Australians' dwindling trust in politicians and the political process, we must also legislate to require truth in political advertising, enhance our media freedom laws, provide better protections for whistleblowers, and significantly overhaul our political donations framework. Which is why today I'm reintroducing the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment (Cleaning up Political Donations) Bill 2023.

And I say reintroduced because when I tabled a similar bill in 2022 it received no support from either major party, which, while shameful, is unsurprising when you look at the vast wads of cash the major parties received in the last financial year.

Indeed figures released by the Australian Electoral Commission earlier this month show an absurd amount of money continues to flow to political parties and candidates, often by big corporate entities. In the 2021-22 financial year, for instance, an election year, I might add, the coalition received $118 million in donations and the Australian Labor Party received $124 million. Which is bad enough in itself, but made all the worse by lax legislation which ensures the public doesn't know where much of that money came from.

For a start, the current disclosure threshold for political donations of $15,200 is way too high, and the current legislation doesn't require donors to disclose if they donate just below the threshold on multiple occasions. So in practice this means, for example, a gambling company can donate $15,199, one dollar below the threshold, on multiple occasions without the public ever knowing about it.
No wonder dark money, money with no identifiable source, reached a record-breaking $119 million last year, or some 40 per cent of political party revenue.
And the situation in Tasmania is even more dire, where the Tasmanian branch of the Liberal Party didn't disclose more than 80 per cent of their donations, and the Labor party almost 90 per cent.

This is plain wrong and my bill will fix it. For a start it lowers the disclosure threshold to $1,000 and requires aggregation, so that multiple donations received from the same source must be disclosed if the sum of all donations meets the threshold.
